'''Baligh ibn Yusuf ibn Tayyi''' (/[[ALA-LC]]: ''Bāligh ibn Yūsuf ibn Ṭayyiʾ'') was the [[Arab]] commander (''muqaddam'') of the ''halqa'' (non-''[[mamluk]]'') regiment of the fortress of [[al-Karak]] in the mid-14th century under the [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluks]]. He was a key backer of Sultan [[an-Nasir Ahmad, Sultan of Egypt|an-Nasir Ahmad]] (r. 1342) during the latter's brief reign. However, he ultimately betrayed an-Nasir Ahmad after being recruited by the latter's brother and usurper of the throne, [[as-Salih Ismail, Sultan of Egypt|as-Salih Ismail]] in 1344. ==Biography== Baligh is rarely mentioned in Mamluk chronicles.Bauden 2004, p. 69. His surname "Tayyi" indicates that he was a member of the [[Tayy]]id tribe of Banu Rabi'ah, though it is not known if he belonged to the [[Al Fadl]] or Al Mira branch.Bauden 2004, p. 70. While the Banu Rabi'ah was the most dominant tribe in Mamluk Syria, the area around [[al-Karak]] was dominated by the [[Banu Uqba]]. During the power struggle following the death of Sultan [[an-Nasir Muhammad]] (r. 1310–1341), Baligh was one of the main backers of the sultan's al-Karak-based son, [[an-Nasir Ahmad, Sultan of Egypt|an-Nasir Ahmad]]. The Mamluk historian [[al-Maqrizi]] wrote that Baligh was Ahmad's "most important confidant among the people of al-Karak",Bauden 2004, p. 68. whose [[Arab]] inhabitants were a well-spring of support for Ahmad.Bauden 2004, pp. 66–67. Ahmad eventually gained the sultanate and moved the Mamluk throne from [[Cairo]] to al-Karak. Baligh officially served as the ''muqaddam'' (commander) of the ''halqa'' (non-''[[mamluk]]'') regiment in al-Karak's fortress. The regiment consisted of [[Bedouin]] tribesmen and locals from the al-Sharat mountains. While Ahmad ruled from al-Karak, the Mamluks in Egypt had him replaced with his half-brother, [[as-Salih Ismail, Sultan of Egypt|as-Salih Ismail]]. Hoping to be rewarded for his loyalty, Baligh continued to support Ahmad during the numerous Mamluk campaigns against al-Karak. On 30 August 1343, Baligh was wounded in the leg during one of the Mamluk expeditions against Ahmad.Bauden, p. 73. However, as Ahmad's "wealth came to depletion", Baligh "began to work upon him", according to al-Maqrizi. Baligh began communications with Ismail via the Mamluk emirs besieging al-Karak. The latter could not be captured because of the resistance of Baligh's Arab troops throughout the vicinity. Baligh promised Ismail he could arrange the surrender of al-Karak, writing
All the people in the fortress of al-Karak are my friends and those in the city are my family and kinsfolk. No one among them contradicts me.
Ismail accepted Baligh's offer, giving him a pardon, after which Baligh escaped al-Karak to meet Ismail in Cairo. He arrived with a coterie of supporters on 21 March 1344, and in return for his defection, was granted an ''[[iqta]]'' (fief) with an annual revenue of 450,000 silver [[dirham]]s and the title of ''amir tablkhana''.Bauden 2004, p. 72. Baligh left Cairo three days later and proceeded to facilitate the surrender of al-Karak and Ahmad to Ismail's troops on 5 July 1344. In August, Baligh and a certain Isa ibn Hasan were arrested on charges of involvement in the murder of a camel merchant in Cairo named Hasan ibn al-Radini. The ''na'ib'' of Cairo sought to punish them by [[bastinado]], but they managed to have the punishment delayed pending further investigation.Bauden 2004, p. 72. Afterward, they used their influence with some Mamluk emirs, who successfully lobbied for their release. This was the final time Baligh was mentioned in Mamluk sources. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last1=Bauden|first1=Frederic|editor1-last=Winter|editor1-first=Michael|editor2-last=Levanoni|editor2-first=Amalia|title=The Mamluks in Egyptian and Syrian Politics and Society|date=2004|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|chapter=The Recovery of Mamluk Chancery Documents in an Unsuspected Place|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NBBMJJTEoKMC&pg=PA63}} *{{cite book|last1=Milwright|first1=Marcus|title=The Fortress of the Raven: Karak in the Middle Islamic Period (1100-1650)|date=2008|publisher=Brill|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XzuwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA83}} {{refend}} [[Category:14th-century Arabs]] [[Category:14th century in the Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)]] [[Category:Tayy]] [[Category:Medieval Jordan]] [[Category:Defectors]]

{{Primarysources|date=October 2010}} [[File:The Committee on World Food Security (CFS) 2015 Logo.png|thumb|Logo of the Committee on World Food Security (CFS) of the United Nations]] The '''Committee on World Food Security''' (CFS) was established in 1974 as an intergovernmental body to serve as a forum in the [[United Nations System]] for review and follow-up of policies concerning world [[food security]] including production and physical and economic access to food. The committee's tasks are to * Coordinate a global approach to food security * Promote policy convergence * Support and advise countries and regions * Coordinate at national and regional levels * Promote accountability and share best practices * Develop a global strategic framework for food security and nutrition ==Structure== ===The CFS Bureau and Advisory Group=== The Bureau is the executive arm of the CFS . It is made up of a Chairperson and twelve member countries. The Advisory group is made up of representatives from the 5 different categories of CFS Participants. These are: 1 UN agencies and other UN bodies;
2 Civil society and non-governmental organizations particularly organizations representing smallholder family farmers, fisherfolks, herders, landless, urban poor, agricultural and food workers, women, youth, consumers and indigenous people;
3 International agricultural research institutions;
4 International and regional financial institutions such as the [[World bank|World Bank]], the [[International Monetary Fund]], regional development banks and the [[Wto|World Trade Organization]];
5 Private sector associations and philanthropic foundations. ===Plenary=== The Plenary session is held annually and is the central body for decision-taking, debate, coordination, lesson-learning and convergence by all stakeholders at a global level on food security issues. ===The High Level Panel of Experts (HLPE)=== The High Level Panel of Experts on Food Security and Nutrition (HLPE) was established in 2010 as the science-policy interface of the UN Committee on World Food Security (CFS). The HLPE aims to improve the robustness of policy making by providing independent, evidence-based analysis and advice at the request of CFS. The HLPE has two components. The first is a steering committee made up of internationally recognized experts in a variety of food security and nutrition-related fields. The second is a roster of experts which is used to build teams that act on a project -specific basis to analyze and report on issues related to food security and nutrition. The goal of the HLPE is to ensure the regular inclusion of advice based on scientific evidence and knowledge. As directed by the CFS Plenary and Bureau, the HLPE will assess and analyze the current state of food security and nutrition and its underlying causes. It will also provide scientific and knowledge-based analysis and advice on policy-relevant issues and identify emerging trends. It will also help prioritize future actions and focus attention on key focal areas. Until today (2013) the HLPE has published 6 reports: # Price volatility and food security (2011) # Land tenure and international investments in agriculture (2011) # Food security and climate change (2012) # Social protection for food security (2012) # Biofuels and food security (2013) # Investing in smallholder agriculture for food security (2013) ===The Secretariat=== The CFS has a permanent Secretariat located in [[Fao|Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)]] headquarters in Rome, Italy which includes members from the [[Wfp|World Food Programme (WFP)]] and the [[IFAD|International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD)]]. Its task is to support the Plenary, the Bureau and Advisory Group and the HLPE in their work. ==External links== * [http://www.fao.org/cfs Official website] * [http://www.fao.org/cfs/cfs-hlpe/en/ Official HLPE website] * [http://km.fao.org/fsn/cfs Online Consultation on the CFS Global Strategic Framework] [[Category:Committees]] [[Category:Food security]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1974]]

'''Counterpropaganda''' is a form of communication consisting of methods taken and messages relayed to oppose [[propaganda]] which seeks to influence [[Action (philosophy)|action]] or perspectives among a targeted [[audience]]. It is closely connected to propaganda as the two often employ the same methods to broadcast methods to a targeted audience. Counterpropaganda differs from propaganda as it is defensive and responsive to identified propaganda. Additionally, counterpropaganda consists of several elements that further distinguish it from propaganda and ensure its effectiveness in opposing propaganda messages.
==Definition== Counterpropaganda and propaganda share a symbiotic relationship. Counterpropaganda is employed in situations to counter existing propaganda efforts and thus to understand the former requires a clear understanding of the latter. Practitioners and academics alike have advanced multiple definitions of propaganda. For the sake of clarity this article acknowledges the definition proposed by Garth Jowett and Victoria O'Donnell who define propaganda as " the deliberate, systematic attempt to shape perceptions, manipulate cognitions, and direct behavior to achieve a response that furthers the desired intent of the propagandist "<ref name="Jowlett and O'Donnell">Garth Jowett and Victoria O'Donnell, ''Propaganda and Persuassion'', 4th ed. Sage Publications, 7.</ref> In practice propaganda consists of communicating a controlled message to a targeted audience. Similarly, counterpropaganda is used to communicate a message that describes the propaganda as false and instructs the target audience to think or act in a manner that counters the propaganda message. To be effective counterpropaganda must target the same audience as the original propaganda message and often may employ the same methods. However, counterpropaganda is unique on its reliance on factual messages, and its existence as a reactionary effort. Since counterpropaganda intends to counter previously stated propaganda messages it cannot be employed preemptively. Counterpropaganda is, however, based upon some of the same fundamentals of propaganda regarding targeting the salient elements that influences audiences.<ref name="Jacques Ellul">{{cite book|author=[[Jacques Ellul|Ellul, Jacques]]|title=[[Propaganda: The Formation of Men's Attitudes]]|date=1973|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0-394-71874-3|edition=Reprinted}}</ref>{{rp|33–36}}
The existing definitions of counterpropaganda differ on their prescription of specified methods and intentions. To illustrate, [[Herbert Romerstein]], former Director of the Office to Counter Soviet [[Disinformation]] and [[Active measures|Active Measures]] at the [[United States Information Agency]], defined Counterpropaganda as "carefully prepared answers to false propaganda with the purpose of refuting the disinformation and undermining the propagandist."<ref name="Herbert Romerstein">{{cite book|last1=Romerstein|first1=Herbert|title="Counterpropaganda: We Can’t Win Without It", in Strategic influence : public diplomacy, counterpropaganda, and political warfare|date=2009|publisher=Institute of World Politics Press|location=Washington, DC|isbn=978-0979223648|pages=137–180|url=http://jmw.typepad.com/files/strategicinfluenceclass_copy.pdf|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> His definition defines the intentions of the counterpropaganda as first countering propaganda and then undermining the credibility of the propagandists. Romerstein's insights are likely influenced by his professional experience in countering Soviet propaganda which was broadcast toward the U.S. through a variety of means. In comparison, Colonel Garrison whose research focuses on the broadcast media as a method of propaganda and public diplomacy provides a more detailed definition of counterpropaganda. He defined counterpropaganda as the "actions to discredit an adversary's use of broadcast media to support their national objectives by influencing the opinions, emotions, attitude, or behavior of U.S. and friendly audiences."<ref name="WC Garrison">{{cite journal|author1=W.C. Garrison |author2=Colonel, U.S. Army |title=Information Operations and Counter-propaganda: Making a Weapon of Public Affairs|url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a363892.pdf|accessdate=3 December 2015|publisher=USAWC strategy research project, U.S. Army War College}}</ref> The focus in this definition is the actions to discredit the propagandists' use of broadcast media. The definition defines counterpropaganda by its usage of broadcast media and its intent to undermine the adversaries biased use of the same medium. The differences in the two demonstrate that counterpropaganda is likely to be defined upon its operational usage and the perspective the definer has toward propaganda. Together both definitions clearly illustrate the symbiotic relationship between propaganda and counterpropaganda. The definitions also demonstrate counterpropaganda, like propaganda, is generally described as a targeted form of communication intending to influence a specific audience. Counterpropaganda merely intends to influence a counter action or thought to a previously broadcast propaganda message or messages.
==Elements of counterpropaganda== While counterpropaganda shares similar traits with propaganda it also consists of unique key elements which define its effective employment.
===Basis in truth=== While propaganda messages may not always be truthful, effective counterpropaganda generally only broadcasts the truth.<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/><ref name="Paul Smith">Paul A. Smith Jr, ''On Political War,'', Washington, D.C.: National Defense University Press, 1989), 7.</ref> Indeed, counterpropaganda is commonly understood to be the "truthful, honest opposition" to an adversary's propaganda.<ref name= "WC Garrison"/> Counterpropaganda communicates truthful messages for moral and practical reasons. During the [[Cold War]], the United States' reputation for broadcasting the truth to refute Soviet propaganda resulted in the U.S. being viewed as a "truth teller" where as the [[Soviet Union]] had a reputation as a "lie teller."<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/> Herbert Romerstein argues that using truth based counterpropaganda resulted in the U.S. being perceived as honest where as the Soviet Union's use of false statements discredited their messages.<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/> This Cold War example demonstrates how a false message is discredited when the truth is revealed. In practice a counterpropaganda message that was intentionally or mistakenly false could be revealed to be as biased as the propaganda it sought to oppose. Thus, telling the truth strengthens the effectiveness of counterpropaganda and weakens the propaganda of those revealed to be liars. The use of [[Deception|false messages]] in counterpropaganda is not effective and fails to adequately refute the propaganda message. Revealing a counterpropaganda message as incorrect or intending to influence via a lie would also harm the broadcaster's reputation and reduce their ability to effectively counter propaganda messages in the future.
====World War II – The Nemmersdorf massacre====
Counterpropaganda based upon a false information is not effective in opposing propaganda messages. This premise is best illustrated by the U.S. failed attempts to counter Germany's claims of Soviet Union committed [[Nemmersdorf massacre|atrocities in Nemmersdorf]], Prussia. When Germany forced the Soviet Union out of the city in October 1944 they found twenty-four dead including twelve women, two teenage girls, a baby, six old men and three school children. Several of the women and teenagers were raped. The Nazi propaganda unit, titled Skorpion, launched a leaflet campaign and sent a letter to [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|General Eisenhower]] to expose the Soviet Union's actions to its American allies. In response America also launched a leaflet campaign and published an article in the March 1, 1945, issue number 49 of its leaflet/newspaper Frontpost titled "Keine Rache" (No Revenge) which quoted Soviet denials of the wrongdoing.<ref name="Frontpost">''Frontpost, Nachrichten für Deutsche Soldaten, Herausgeber: Die Amerikanischen Truppen in Westeuropa,'' No. 1(March 1945), 3 in Waller, ed., ''Strategic Influence: Public Diplomacy, Counterpropaganda and Political Warfare'' (IWP Press, 2008), 144-145.</ref> The false messages in American counterpropaganda failed to effectively oppose [[Propaganda in Nazi Germany|German propaganda]] and failed to change German's perspectives toward the Soviet Union. The counterpropaganda campaign also did little to enforce America's reputation for honesty among German soldiers. When revealed false counterpropaganda damages the reputation of the broadcaster and limits his/her ability to counter propaganda in the future.
[[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-464-0383I-26, Nemmersdorf (Ostpreußen), ermordete Deutsche.jpg|thumb|250px|Dead Germans in Nemmersdorf, Oct. 1944, German Federal Archive]]
===Clarity=== Counterpropaganda messages relying on words or concepts not universally understood fail to adequately communicate to the target audience and are ineffective in opposing propaganda. Using understandable words to clearly convey the counterpropaganda message is more likely to counter propaganda messages.
===="Unconditional surrender" in World War II====
The converse is equally true. The use of the phrase "unconditional surrender" in World War II is a prime example of the importance of clarity. The phrase conveyed scary images to the Germans and the Japanese. Some experts proposed that the phrase would cause greater resistance against the allies because the term was not clearly conveyed to the target audience. The confusion required the U.S. and Britain to explain the message which resulted in reducing its effectiveness.<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/>
====Coalition messages in Iraq====
Andrew Garfield explained that the Coalition messages in [[Iraq]] routinely referred to insurgents as "anti-Iraqis" which caused ambiguity in the coalition's counterpropaganda messages. The phrase did not adequately coincide with the descriptions various Iraqi communities prescribed insurgents. As a result, the phrase failed to convey the message the Coalition sought to convey.<ref name="Andrew Garfield">{{cite book|last1=Garfield|first1=Andrew|title="Recovering the Lost Art of Counterpropaganda: An interim assessment of the war of ideas in Iraq", in Strategic influence : public diplomacy, counterpropaganda, and political warfare|date=2009|publisher=Institute of World Politics Press|location=Washington, DC|isbn=978-0979223648|pages=181–196|url=http://jmw.typepad.com/files/strategicinfluenceclass_copy.pdf|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> Counterpropaganda messages that require explanations for clarity fail to adequately communicate the intended message and thus fail to oppose propaganda.
===Knowledge of the audience=== Counterpropaganda, like propaganda, requires developing messages understanding of the [[target audience]] and the ability to tailor the message appropriately. Effective counterpropaganda relies on communicating messages that "resonate with the target audiences" and that are based on culturally relevant narratives. More precisely, developing messages that are effective in a target audience entails identifying the existing sentiments, stereotypes and opinions that influence the audience's perspectives, beliefs and actions.<ref name="Jacques Ellul"/>{{rp|34}}<ref name="Andrew Garfield"/> In considering these elements of a society, propaganda and counterpropaganda can influence a group toward a particular perspective or action.<ref name="Jacques Ellul"/>{{rp|34–36}} Since the objective of counterpropaganda is to influence an audience to reject a propaganda message, it must touch upon the elements of culture, belief and emotion that will result in such action. The elements will vary among audiences and while propaganda and counterpropaganda campaigns can and do utilize existing methods the messages must be tailored specifically to the individual target audience.
===Employed rapidly=== Counterpropaganda is a reactive method that must be employed rapidly to effectively contradict a propaganda message. [[Oliver Carlson]] explains that the longer propaganda is perceived as the truth the harder it is to contradict even when the target audience is exposed to an opposing true message.<ref name="Oliver Carlson">{{cite journal|last1=Carlson|first1=Oliver|title=Handbook on propaganda for the alert citizen|journal=Studies of the Foundation for Social Research|volume=2|issue=1|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Handbook_on_propaganda_for_the_alert_cit.html?id=HwrTAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> A propaganda message that is not contradicted immediately upon its discovery is likely to become the basis the target audience's actions and beliefs.
Psychology provides additional reasons to rapidly employ counterpropaganda. The decision making process is influenced by [[cognitive biases]] which shape how a person perceives certain pieces of information and how they will act upon them. The [[confirmation bias]] is especially relevant when explaining the necessity of employing counterpropaganda rapidly. Confirmation bias is a tendency for people to favor information confirming their beliefs or hypotheses.<ref name="Scott Plous">Scott Plous, ''The Psychology of Judgment and Decision Making McGraw Hill, 1993, 233.</ref><ref name="Science Daily">ScienceDaily. Confirmation Bias. https://www.sciencedaily.com/articles/c/confirmation_bias.htm(accessed 4/14/2012)</ref> If a group based their beliefs or actions upon a propaganda message they were exposed to over or during a long period of time it is difficult to counter the propaganda. The group in such a scenario would be hesitant to assimilate any information from a counterpropaganda message that contradicted the propaganda message. Thus, it is important for counterpropaganda be employed early in a propaganda campaign to prevent the possibility of confirmation bias resulting from propaganda. In ''[[Propaganda: The Formation of Men's Attitudes]]'', [[Jacques Ellul]] suggests another reason to employ counterpropaganda quickly in response to an identified propaganda message. He argues that humankind is more concerned with current events and issues that hold the society's attention. Propaganda shaped upon current events will invoke the greatest amount of community passion and interest.<ref name="Jacques Ellul"/>{{rp|46, 49}} Countering propaganda, requires a quick response to propaganda when it is revealed. Conversely, employing counterpropaganda against a dated propaganda message that regards an equally dated issue that society holds no current interest is likely to be less effective.
==Methods of counterpropaganda== Counterpropaganda intends to broadcast messages aimed at refuting and/or countering propaganda messages and thus many of the effective propaganda methods are equally effective in broadcasting counterpropaganda. However, counterpropaganda utilizes a few unique techniques that are effective in attacking propaganda's credibility and ability to influence a target audience.
===Research and analysis=== Effective counterpropaganda begins by fully collecting and analyzing the propaganda to be countered. The metaphor explaining this function is simple; to counter a propaganda message it is necessary to fully understand the message, its target audience and its objectives. Success in countering propaganda requires a "comprehensive propaganda monitoring and collection effort" that identifies and catalogues examples of all types of adversarial propaganda. This initial method of counterpropaganda benefits from experts in a range of disciplines to include intelligence psychological operations, social science, cultural anthropologists, etc. who are capable of analyzing the propaganda. Expert analysis can properly dissect the propaganda to provide answers to the following questions necessary to form an effective counterpropaganda effort:<ref name="Andrew Garfield"/> * Who is the intended audience? * What effects do the propagandists desire? * What effects have they achieved? * Which other audiences have heard or seen this message? * What do these messages indicate about an adversary's perceptions, capabilities, vulnerabilities, and intent? * What are the intentional or unintentional inaccuracies, inconsistencies, or deceits in the messages that we can exploit? * What counter arguments can we deploy, to whom, and how?
===Reveal true origin of propaganda=== Oliver Carlson explains in the Handbook of Propaganda: For the Alert Citizen that the "Best propaganda is that which does not disclose itself as propaganda." <ref name="Oliver Carlson"/>{{rp|105}} There are three types of propaganda which differ depending upon their attribution. White propaganda reveals its origin and generally classified as overt. Covert propaganda includes grey propaganda in which the source is not revealed and black propaganda in which a false origin is claimed (the episode at the 1984 Olympics described below is an example of "black propaganda").<ref name="Alfred H. Paddock Jr.">Alfred H. Paddock Jr., "Legitimizing Army Psychological Operations," ''Joint Forces Quarterly,'' Issue 56, 2010, 90, http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a515093.pdf (accessed April 15, 20120).</ref> In the later two types of propaganda the message's origin is concealed in some way. Often the credibility of a propaganda message depends on masking the true origin of the message to ensure the audience accepts it as an unbiased communication. Often propagandists will create a persona that is "reliable, trustworthy and credible" to the target audience which increases the likelihood that the message is believed and influences the audience's actions and perspectives.<ref name="George Mason University">''Propaganda,''{{cite web |url=https://mason.gmu.edu/~amcdonal/Purpose%20of%20Propaganda.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430161238/http://mason.gmu.edu/~amcdonal/Purpose%20of%20Propaganda.html |archivedate=2012-04-30 |df= }} (Accessed April 8, 2012).</ref> When counterpropaganda reveals the propaganda's true origin the target audience quickly loses faith in the message as the propagandist was caught lying.<ref name="George Mason University"/><ref name="Anthony Rhodes">Anthony Rhodes, ''Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion World War II,''(New York:Chelsea House Publications, 1976), 287.</ref>
====The 1984 Los Angeles Olympics====
During the months leading up to the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] hosted by Los Angeles, the Soviet Union circulated forged Ku Klux Klan leaflets threatening the lives of non-white athletes. The Soviet Union sent the leaflets specifically to the African and Asian Olympic Committees. The U.S. State Department released a public statement accusing the KGB of producing the leaflets and notified each Olympic committee that the leaflets were forgeries. The result was no single Olympic committee refused to attend the games and the Soviets were revealed as the origin of the propaganda.<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/>
===Expose reasoning errors=== Propagandists exploit [[cognitive biases]] and other elements of decision making to shape their messages to influence the target audience. In this sense they are able to insert a propaganda message into a target audience's logic to make that message more believable and credible. Specifically, propagandists deliberately use errors in arguments to appeal to the emotions of their audience.<ref name="George Mason University"/> When a counterpropaganda campaign exposes the target audience's errors in judgment and resolves them the propaganda message loses strength. This counterpropaganda method works similarly as reveal the true origin of a propaganda message as it exposes the broadcaster as a liar which reduces its credibility. Furthermore, when made aware of logical fallacies in its reasoning, the target audience will soon reject any message that was based on this faulty reasoning. A competing perspective suggests that propaganda is based upon emotional reactions not cognitive reasoning. Carlson argues propaganda is developed as much as possible to focus on people's emotions versus their rational.<ref name="Oliver Carlson"/>{{rp|16–17}} This argument suggests propaganda is minimally based upon reasoning and logic and that exposing a group's logical errors is ineffective in refuting propaganda messages.<ref name="Philip M. Taylor">Philip M. Taylor,''Munitions of the Mind: A History of Propaganda from the Ancient World to the Present Day, (Manchester and New York:Manchester University Press, 1995),15.</ref>
Jacques Ellul presents another basis for propaganda which suggests exposing a group's faulty reasoning is not an effective method to oppose propaganda. He argues that the speed at which events occur, become out dated and no longer of interest cause mankind to have little patience for using attention and awareness to closely examine current events. The individual is interested only in the superficial element of particular events, which is one reason propaganda is effective.<ref name="Jacques Ellul"/>{{rp|47}} It is, therefore, difficult to draw an audience's attention to the minutiae necessary to highlight flaws in their reasoning which make a propaganda message effective. Yet, Ellul further elaborates that this counterpropaganda message is critical to instruct a group to defend itself against propaganda as it exposes an audience's vulnerability to propaganda based upon our own mental vulnerabilities.<ref name="Jacques Ellul"/>{{rp|257}}
===Dissemination of exposed propaganda=== Effective propaganda is tailored to a particular audience and when it is shared to another group the message is clearly revealed as an influencing message. Some audiences are more sophisticated and techniques that work on comparably less developed nations will be ineffective with the former. When a counterpropaganda campaign shares propaganda intended for a specific audience with another audience the propagandists' true intentions are revealed. The sharing of propaganda messages between audiences also enables the second audience to reveal propaganda messages targeting them. In the 1980s, during the Cold War, the United States shared examples of Soviet disinformation targeting the Third World with European nations. The Europeans were then able to identify Soviet propaganda targeting them. The sharing of propaganda damaged the Soviet Union's reputation in Europe during a time it sought Western approval.<ref name="Herbert Romerstein"/> Thus, countering propaganda by demonstrating it to be outright lies, or intending to influence reduces its effectiveness across target audiences.

{{Infobox person |name = Darren Kimura |image = Darren Kimura.jpg | caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|09|10}} |birth_place = [[Hilo, Hawaii]] |residence = [[Palo Alto, California]] and [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] |known_for = Inventor of [[Solar thermal energy#MicroCSP|MicroCSP]] |occupation = [[Entrepreneur]], [[Investor]], [[Inventor]] |website = {{url|https://twitter.com/darrentkimura/}} {{url|http://www.darrentkimura.com/}} | home_town = [[Palo Alto, CA]] |title = [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Energy Industries Corporation]],
[[Chair (official)|Chairman]] of [[LiveAction]] }} '''Darren T. Kimura''' (born September 10, 1974, [[Hilo, Hawaii]]) is an American businessman, inventor, and investor. He is best known as the inventor of Micro [[Concentrated solar power]] (CSP) technology{{cite news|title=Niche Markets for micro-CSP Page|url=http://social.csptoday.com/emerging-markets/niche-markets-micro-csp}}{{cite news|title=MicroCSP - Concentrating Solar Power|url=http://www.altenergymag.com/emagazine/2011/10/microcsp-concentrated-solar-power/1804}} otherwise known as MicroCSP.{{cite web|title=United States Patent and Trademark Office Trademark MicroCSP|url=http://trade.mar.cx/US77241333/}} == Life == Kimura was born to [[Japanese American]] parents in [[Hilo, Hawaii]] and graduated from [[Waiakea High School]].{{cite web|title=Darren T. Kimura Class of 1992|url=http://waiakeahigh.k12.hi.us/library/NaMea%20Pages/Darren%20Kimura.htm}} He achieved the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] as a member in the [[Boy Scouts of America]]. He studied Computer Science and Business Management at the [[University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa]]. He later attended [[Portland State University]], studying Electrical Engineering and [[Stanford University]] studying Computer Science. During the 2009 flu pandemic, ''[[Newsweek]]'' covered Darren’s challenges in finding [[Tamiflu]] for his wife Kelly due to hoarding.{{cite news|title=Newsweek: Why individual stockpiling of anti-flu medication is a bad idea|url=http://mag.newsweek.com/2009/04/30/healthy-hoarders.html}} == Career == Kimura began his career as an entrepreneur bringing the sport of [[paintball]] to Hawaii while still in high school.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} When attending the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] he worked in the Information and Computer Sciences department, where he launched Nalu Communications, an [[internet service provider]].{{cite web|title=Saipan Tribune Rountable|url=http://www.saipantribune.com/newsstory.aspx?newsID=60624&cat=1}} Later he created and expanded Energy Industries Corporation. With the support of Energy Industries he created Energy Laboratories,{{cite web|title=Energy Laboratories|url=http://www.energylaboratories.com/?page_id=2}} as an incubator for start-up companies, and Enerdigm Ventures,{{cite web|title=Enerdigm Ventures|url=http://enerdigm.com/wp/}} a venture capital firm to seed and support early to growth stage companies. MicroCSP Technology and [[Sopogy]], Inc. began as a spin-off of at Energy Laboratories and was initially funded by Kimura and Enerdigm Ventures.{{cite web|title=Sopogy closes Series E funding |url=http://www.altassets.net/private-equity-news/by-news-type/deal-news/us-solar-developer-sopogy-closes-series-e-funding-round.html}} Kimura and Enerdigm Ventures invested in the creation of [[LiveAction]] as a spin-out from Referentia a government contractor.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2014/02/11/darren-kimura-named-ceo-of-live-action.html|title=Darren Kimura named CEO of Live Action - Pacific Business News|website=bizjournals.com|access-date=2018-08-01}} He also supported the construction of the world’s first MicroCSP project, called [[Holaniku at Keahole Point]].{{cite web|title=Sopogy inaugurates the World’s first MicroCSP solar thermal plant using Sopogy’s products |url=http://sopogy.com/blog/2009/12/10/sopogy-inaugurates-the-world%E2%80%99s-first-microcsp%E2%84%A2-solar-thermal-plant/}}{{cite web|title=Sopogy introduces new solar technology at NELHA |url=http://www.hawaii247.com/2009/12/11/sopogy-introduces-new-solar-technology-at-nelha/}} He served as a director to the State of Hawaii Venture Capital fund.{{cite web|title=HSDC Annual Report|url=http://lrbhawaii.info/reports/legrpts/dbedt/hsdc/211f_15hrs_11.pdf}} His entrepreneurial accomplishments has led him to be featured on the cover of ''[[MidWeek]]'',{{cite news|title=Midweek: The future’s so bright|url=http://archives.midweek.com/content/story/midweek_coverstory/Darren_Kimura_Energy_Conservation_and_Management_Hawaii_/ }} on the cover of ''Pacific Edge'',{{cite news|title=Pacific Edge: The Energy Within |url=http://viewer.zmags.com/publication/b9bdde2b#/b9bdde2b/1}} in ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]'',{{cite web|title=Entrepreneur Magazine: Riding the Green Wave |url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/196570}} and in the 2007 book ''The Greater Good: Life Lessons from Hawaii's Leaders''.{{cite news|title=The Greater Good: Crazy to Visionary |url=http://www.greatergoodbooks.com/The_Greater_Good-sneak_peek.pdf}} He was also a live guest with [[Al Gore]] on [[The Climate Reality Project]] on ''[[24 Hours of Reality|24 Hours of Reality – The Dirty Weather Report]]''.{{cite web|title=The World's Oceans & Hawaii|url=http://climaterealityproject.org/24hours2012/live-broadcast/hour-06-the-worlds-oceans/}} He was featured in the [[Hawaiian Electric Company]]'s [[clean energy]] promotion, which was highlighted during the [[APEC United States 2011]].{{cite web|title=Hawaiian Electric Green Energy|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCGM5y07TNU&feature=youtu.be}} === Energy Industries Corporation === Kimura started Energy Conservation Hawaii in 1994,{{cite web|title=The Future’s So Bright…|url=http://archives.midweek.com/content/story/midweek_coverstory/Darren_Kimura_Energy_Conservation_and_Management_Hawaii_/}} from the back of his [[SUV]],{{cite news|title=Success built on CEO’s work ethic|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Nov/08/bz/FP611080319.html}} using his surfboard as his desk.{{cite web|title=From surfer to renewable energy entrepreneur|url=http://www.bizgym.com/2009/08/green-success-story-daren-kimura-trades-in-his-surfboard-for-a-thriving-renewable-energy-business/}} In a few years the company reached $50 million in revenues and began national expansion.{{cite web|title=Success build on CEO’s work ethic |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Nov/08/bz/FP611080319.html}} Kimura changed the company name to Energy Industries Corporation to appeal to its national markets, and he remains the largest shareholder. The underlying concept for creating Energy Industries Corporation was to help make energy efficiency simple. In his work at Energy Industries Corporation, Kimura provided [[Energy Star]] consulting services in such locations as Hawaii,{{cite web|title=Hawaii Business: Energy Savers|url=http://www.hawaiibusiness.com/Hawaii-Business/May-2001/Light-Savers/}} Palau,{{cite web|title=Energy Star in Palau|url=http://darrentkimura.com/2006/01/27/energy-star-in-palau/ }} Guam{{cite web|title=Energy Star in Guam |url=http://darrentkimura.com/2006/01/25/energy-star-in-guam/}} and Saipan.{{cite web|title=Energy Division sponsors energy-saving workshop |url=http://www.saipantribune.com/newsstory.aspx?cat=1&newsID=60711}} Energy Industries Corporation was featured in the 2008 ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' article "Alternative State", about renewable energy projects created in Hawaii.{{cite news|title=Wall Street Journal Alternative State|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121432274606000209 | work=The Wall Street Journal}} === MicroCSP === {{Main|Solar thermal energy#MicroCSP}} The concept for MicroCSP technologies were created when Kimura attempted to install a conventional Concentrating Solar Power trough in Kona, Hawaii. Realizing that it was uneconomical and not practical to ship, install and operate such large components in remote locations like Hawaii, Kimura worked on reducing the dimensions of the solar collector which led to reconfiguring the technology and incorporating the use of state of the art materials.{{cite web|title=MicroCSP Beginnings |url=http://www.altenerg.com/back_issues/index.php-content_id=409.htm}} MicroCSP is used for community-sized power plants (1 MW to 50 MW), for industrial, agricultural and manufacturing 'process heat' applications, and when large amounts of hot water are needed, such as resort swimming pools, water parks, large laundry facilities, sterilization, distillation and other such uses.{{cite web|title= MicroCSP Uses|url=http://www.estif.org/fileadmin/estif/content/policies/downloads/D23-solar-industrial-process-heat.pdf}} MIT also studied the use of MicroCSP technology in power generation using the Organic Rankine Cycle.{{cite web|title=MicroCSP Beginnings |url=http://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/88278}} Kimura trademarked the term MicroCSP {{cite web|title=MicroCSP Trademark |url=http://tmsearch.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=doc&state=4801:m8l02j.2.2}} and later released the term for use in the public domain to help accelerate MicroCSP adoption. His [[US]] [[Patent]] on the idea ({{US patent|20080127967}}) served as the basis for other MicroCSP inventions. Companies producing MicroCSP technologies include [[Rackam]], [[GlassPoint Solar]] {{cite web|title=CSP Today Glasspoint Solar markets |url=http://social.csptoday.com/markets/micro-csp-still-looking-good-sopogy%E2%80%99s-wake}} Abengoa Solar {{cite web|title=Abengoa Solar for Industrial Applications website |url= http://www.abengoasolar.com/web/en/nuestros_productos/aplicaciones_industriales/}} Aora {{cite web|title=Aora cuts blue ribbon |url=http://cleantechnica.com/2012/02/09/aora-cuts-blue-ribbon-on-europes-first-hybrid-micro-csp-demonstration/}} Sun2Power{{cite web|title=Sun2Power|url=http://www.kcorc.org/en/rd-projects/sun2power-micro-solar-csp-plant/}} Chromasun {{cite web|title=Chromasun |url=http://chromasun.com/images/content/presentations/SPI2011%20Chromasun%20Peter%20Le%20Lievre.pdf}} SolarLite {{cite web|title=SolarLite|url=http://solarlite-csp.com/en/power_plants.cfm}} NEP Solar {{cite web|title=NEP Solar website|url=http://www.nep-solar.com/}} Novatec Solar {{cite web|title=Novatec Solar website |url=http://www.novatecsolar.com/}} Industrial Solar{{cite web|title=Industrial Solar|url= http://www.industrial-solar.de/CMS/}} Focal Point Energy{{cite web|title=Focal Point|url=http://focalpointenergy.com/product/}} SunTrough {{cite web|title=Suntrough website|url=http://suntrough.com/}} Focused Sun {{cite web|title=US' Focused Sun and China's Xiang Yang Institute partner to develop micro-CSP systems|url=http://www.csp-world.com/news/20150107/001637/us-focused-sun-and-chinas-xiang-yang-institute-partner-develop-micro-csp}} Heat 2 Power {{cite web|title=Energía solar micro-CSP|url=http://www.consumer.es/web/es/medio_ambiente/energia_y_ciencia/2010/05/24/193252.php}} and Nanogen{{cite web|title=Nanogen|url=http://www.sustainablebusiness.com/index.cfm/go/news.display/id/21935}} and Tamuz Energy.{{Cite web|url=http://tamuz-energy.com/|title=Tamuz Energy Website|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} === Sopogy === {{Main|Sopogy}} Sopogy, a solar thermal technology supplier, was founded in 2002 at the Honolulu, Hawaii–based clean technology incubator known as Energy Laboratories.{{cite web|title=Sopogy Website|url=http://sopogy.com/company/}} The company began its research on concentrating solar thermal energy to produce solar steam and thermal heat for absorption chillers or industrial process heat. The company has also developed applications that incorporate its solar collectors to generate electricity and desalination. Kimura created the company name from taking sections of key words including "SO" from Solar, "PO" from "Power", and "GY" from "Energy and Technology".{{cite web | title=About Sopogy |url=http://sopogy.com/about/index.php?id=16#3 }} The company's [[OEM]] and [[Independent Power Producer|IPP]] sales teams are located in [[Honolulu]] along with its [[research and development]],{{cite news|title=Sopogy returns to Manoa Innovation Center|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/2013/06/sopogy-inc-returns-to-original-office.html}} and in 2006 it expanded its manufacturing, [[C&I]], and [[oil and gas]] sales teams in its [[Silicon Valley]] facility.{{cite web|title=Hawaii tech firms move offices and expand facilities to Mainland|url=http://sopogy.com/blog/2007/12/28/hawaii-tech-firms-move-offices-and-expand-facilities-to-mainland/}} Sopogy has installed 200 megawatts in China,{{cite web|title=Sopogy announced the installation of 200 megawatts of CSP in China|url=http://www.helioscsp.com/noticia.php?id_not=269}}{{cite web|title=Sopogy Lands 200MW China Project for Thermal Storage |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/blog/post/2010/12/sopogy-lands-200mw-china-project-for-thermal-energy-storage}} and 360 megawatts in Thailand.{{cite web|title=Sopogy signs agreement on Thai solar project|url=http://www.renewableenergyfocus.com/view/19449/sopogy-signs-agreement-on-thai-solar-project/}} Kimura and Sopogy, along with [[First Solar]], were featured in the [[Whole Foods Market]] documentary ''Thrive''.{{cite web|title=Whole Foods features Sopogy and First Solar |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uDNavtgu9yc&feature=youtu.be }} In 2011 Sopogy was honored with the [[APEC]] Business Innovation Award,{{cite web|title=Sopogy is APEC Honolulu technology showcase winner|url=http://www.ustr.gov/about-us/press-office/blog/2011/november/apec-business-spotlight-sopogy-apec-honolulu-technology-sho}} and was featured on the cover of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.{{cite news|title=Darren Kimura, CEO of Sopogy, at the firm's solar facility on Hawaii's Big Island|url=http://www.latimes.com/lat-fi-green-haw_kw5gonc,0,2184478.photo#axzz2oPmanlY1 | work=Los Angeles Times}} [[File:Darren Kimura at US Japan Council 2013.jpg|thumb|Darren Kimura at the [[U.S.-Japan Council]] 2013]] Sopogy completed a Series E preferred financing in October 2012 led by [[Mitsui & Co.]] and [[SunEdison]], a U.S. solar company, [[Sempra Energy]], [[3M]], and others.{{cite web|title=Sopogy strengthens its financial status|url=http://www.csp-world.com/news/20121203/00635/sopogy-strengthens-its-financial-status}} The company announced that Darren Kimura had stepped down as the chairman, chief executive officer and president in March 2013, and SunEdison installed one of its executives as president of the company.{{cite news|title=Sopogy Names SunEdison Exec to top leadership role|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/article/2013-03-19/arQyXkwW7p_k.html | work=Bloomberg}} After completing a hand-over period, Darren Kimura left the company in May 2013.{{cite web|title=Darren Kimura Blog - What's next?|url=http://darrentkimura.com/2013/07/27/whats-next/}} Sopogy was acquired by Hitachi Power Systems in 2014.{{cite web|title=MicroCSP still looking good in Sopogy's wake|url=http://social.csptoday.com/markets/micro-csp-still-looking-good-sopogy%E2%80%99s-wake}} === LiveAction === {{Main|LiveAction}} Enerdigm Ventures invested in LiveAction, an enterprise network management software company founded in 2007 at Referentia Systems, Inc.{{cite web|title=ActionPacked Networks Rebrands and Launches as LiveAction|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2014/02/prweb11547284.htm}} and Kimura joined the company as Chairman of the Board of Directors, Executive Chairman{{cite web|title=LiveAction Leadership Team|url=http://actionpacked.com/company/team}} and later as Chief Executive Officer.{{cite web|title=Darren Kimura joins LiveAction as Chief Executive Officer |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2014/02/11/darren-kimura-named-ceo-of-live-action.html}} The Company is best known for its [[NetFlow]] visualization capabilities{{cite web|title=Network Visualization Tool Now Supports 1M Flows Per Second|url=http://www.tmcnet.com/voip/departments/articles/325549-actionpacked-network-visualization-tool-now-supports-1m-flows.htm}} and [[Quality of Service]] monitoring and configuration capabilities.{{cite web|title=Cisco: Rule the World of Application QoS|url=http://blogs.cisco.com/enterprise/rule-the-world-of-application-qos-with-cisco-avc-and-actionpacked-networks/}} Kimura led LiveAction to achieve a place on the Cisco Solutions Plus Program {{cite web|title=LiveAction Cisco GPL|url=http://technews.tmcnet.com/networkmanagementreport/topics/networkmanagementreport/articles/377330-better-network-management-with-liveaction.htm}} and completed LiveAction's Series A financing that included participation by Enerdigm Ventures,{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140904006444/en/LiveAction-Secures-5.35-Million-Series-Financing-AITV|title=LiveAction Secures $5.35 Million Series A Financing from AITV and Cisco Investments|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}} AITV and [[Cisco Systems]] {{cite web|title=LiveAction Secures $5.35 Million Series A Financing from AITV and Cisco Investments |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/09/04/liveaction-secures-5-35-million-series-a-financing-from-aitv-and-cisco-investments/}} LiveAction expanded its capabilities in scale to achieve an industry leading 1 million flows per second{{Cite web | url = http://www.tmcnet.com/voip/departments/articles/325549-actionpacked-network-visualization-tool-now-supports-1m-flows.htm | title = ActionPacked! Network Visualization Tool Now Supports 1M Flows Per Second | website = www.tmcnet.com | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} and began expanding as a network visualization platform including capabilities in [[Software-defined networking|Software Defined Networking]] and SD-WAN.{{Cite web | url = https://www.enterprisemanagement.com/research/asset-free.php/3083/pre/LiveAction:-The-Visibility-Assurance-Solution-for-Cisco-Intelligent-WAN-pre | title = LiveAction the Visibility Solution | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = }} Under Kimura, LiveAction launched LiveAgent to extend visibility to the network end point{{Cite news|url=https://www.liveaction.com/resources/solution-briefs/liveagent-solution-brief/|title=LiveAgent Solution Brief - The Endpoint Visibility Challenge|work=LiveAction|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}} and LiveAction completed a $36 million Series B financing led by [[Insight Venture Partners]], [[Cisco Systems]] and AITV in early 2016.{{Cite web | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160215005756/en/LiveAction-Secures-36-Million-Series-Financing-Insight | title = LiveAction Secures $36 Million Series B Financing from Insight Venture Partners, Accelerate-IT Ventures, and Cisco Investments {{!}} Business Wire | website = www.businesswire.com | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} In December 2017, Kimura led the acquisition of LivingObjects' Service Provider network monitoring platform{{Cite news|url=https://www.liveaction.com/company/press-releases/liveaction-acquires-living-objects-network-monitoring-platform/|title=LiveAction Acquires LivingObjects’ Network Monitoring Platform|work=LiveAction|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}} and to the creation of the LiveSP business unit at LiveAction.{{Cite news|url=https://www.liveaction.com/company/press-releases/launch-livesp-network-monitoring-solution/|title=LiveAction Bolsters Commitment to Global Managed Network Services Market with Launch of LiveSP Network Monitoring Solution|work=LiveAction|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}} In June 2018, Kimura led the acquisition of Savvius{{Cite news|url=https://www.liveaction.com/company/press-releases/liveaction-acquires-leading-packet-capture-savvius/|title=LiveAction Acquires Leading Packet Capture Savvius, Inc.|work=LiveAction|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}} formerly known as WildPackets{{Cite web|url=https://betanews.com/2015/04/16/wildpackets-becomes-savvius-and-switches-focus-to-security/|title=WildPackets becomes Savvius and switches focus to security|website=betanews.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}} famous for their [[OmniPeek]] protocol analysis software. ==Awards== Kimura received the 2002 [[Small Business Administration|SBA]] Young Entrepreneur of the Year award.{{cite news |title=No small success Page|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2002/03/12/business/index2.html}} He was honored as the 2007 Green Entrepreneur,{{cite news|title=Darren T. Kimura wins Green Entrepreneur of the Year Award|url=http://altenergymag.com/news_detail.php?pr_id=3246}} and received the Blue Planet Foundation award in 2009.{{cite news|title=Darren T. Kimura receives Blue Planet Foundation Award |url=http://social.csptoday.com/technology/sopogy-ceo-receives-blue-planet-foundation-award}} He also received the Hawaii Venture Capital Association Deal of the Year award in 2012.{{cite news|title=Entrepreneur, Deal of the Year awards announced |url=http://www.hawaiistar.com/2013/01/entrepreneur-deal-of-the-year-awards-announced/}} He was named to the 2010 ''[[Hawaii Business Magazine]]''{{'}}s "10 for Today", along with other Hawaii luminaries such as professional baseball player [[Shane Victorino]], and founder of [[eBay]], [[Pierre Omidyar]],{{cite news|title=Hawaii Business Magazine: 10 For Today |url=http://www.hawaiibusiness.com/Hawaii-Business/March-2010/10-For-Today/}} and was named to the ''[[Pacific Business News]]''{{'}}s "10 to Watch in 2013",{{cite news|title=10 to Watch: Hawaii business leaders face risks and rewards in 2013 |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2013/01/04/10-to-watch-hawaii-business-leaders.html}} along with video game developer and video game [[Tetris]] distributor [[Henk Rogers]]. ==Non-profit activities== Kimura is active in community and philanthropic activities with a strong focus on Hawaii. He serves as vice president and director at Blue Planet Foundation,{{cite web|title=Blue Planet Foundation Board of Directors|url=http://blueplanetfoundation.org/board-of-directors.html}} and vice president and director at SEE-IT (Science Engineering Exposition of Innovative Technologies),{{cite web|title=SEE-IT Foundation Board of Directors|url=http://see-it-hawaii.com/contact-us/}} He is also on the board of directors at [[PBS Hawaii]],{{cite web|title=PBS Hawaii Board of Directors|url=http://www.pbshawaii.org/about/about_boardofdirectors.php}} is [[entrepreneur-in-residence]] at [[Punahou School]],{{cite web|title=Punahou Entrepreneur in Residence|url=http://www.punahou.edu/luke-center-for-public-service/entrepreneurs-in-residence/index.aspx}} is on the board of directors at Enterprise Honolulu, the Oahu Economic Development Board,{{cite web|title=Enterprise Honolulu|url=http://www.enterprisehonolulu.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=5}} and is on the Dean's Council of [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]]'s College of Engineering.{{cite web|title=College of Engineering Dean's Council|url=http://www.eng.hawaii.edu/about/deans-council/}} Kimura sponsors the Hawaii Island Science Fair "Kimura Award for Innovations in Clean Energy{{Cite web|url=pic.twitter.com/jyyU0cYRIb|title=Twitter Hawaii Science Fair|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}" which was awarded to Felix Peng (2016) of [[Waiakea High School]],{{Cite web | url = http://hilo.hawaii.edu/affiliates/sigmaxi/documents/AwardsListing2016RESULTS.pdf | title = Hawaii Island Science Fair 2016 | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = }} Ben Kubo (2017) of [[Parker School (Kamuela, Hawaii)|Parker School]], Cesar Rivera (2017) of [[St. Joseph High School (Hilo, Hawaii)|St Joseph School of Hilo]]. Also in 2017, Kimura expanded the Hawaii Island Science Fair award to include the "Kimura Award for Innovations in Computer Science"{{Cite web|url=http://darrentkimura.com/1333-2/|title=Kimura Award Winners for IT and Clean Energy 2017 {{!}} Darren T. Kimura|website=darrentkimura.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-01}} which was awarded to Ara Uhr of [[Hilo High School]]. == See also == {{Portal|Renewable energy|Energy|Sustainable development}} * [[List of people associated with renewable energy]] * [[List of solar thermal power stations]] * [[SolarPACES]] * [[Solar thermal collector]] * [[Intersolar]] == References == {{Reflist |30em}} == External links == * {{Official website}} *[http://www.energy-industries.com Energy Industries Corporation] *[http://www.sopogy.com/ Sopogy] *[http://www.enerdigm.com/ Enerdigm Group] *[https://twitter.com/darrentkimura Darren Kimura Twitter Page] {{Solar energy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kimura, Darren}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Japanese descent]] [[Category:American technology chief executives]] [[Category:American technology company founders]] [[Category:People from Hilo, Hawaii]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Portland State University alumni]] [[Category:Sustainability advocates]] [[Category:People associated with renewable energy]] [[Category:University of Hawaii alumni]] [[Category:People associated with solar power]] [[Category:Silicon Valley people]] [[Category:Eagle Scouts]] [[Category:American businesspeople of Japanese descent]]

{{Infobox Political Party | name = Dhofar Liberation Front | native_name = جبهة تحرير ظفار | logo = | leader = | colorcode = red | colors = | foundation = 1965 | dissolved = 1968 | founder = | ideology = [[Arab nationalism]]
[[Marxism]] | slogan = | predecessor = | successor = [[Popular Front for the Liberation of the Occupied Arabian Gulf]]| headquarters = | international = [[Arab Nationalist Movement]]| website = | flag = [[File:Flag of the Dhofar Liberation Front.svg|200px]] | |country=Oman}} '''Dhofar Liberation Front''' (DLF) ({{lang-ar|جبهة تحرير ظفار}}) was a [[communist]] front which was established to create a separatist state in [[Dhofar]], the southern province of [[Oman]], which shared a border with [[South Yemen]].{{cite web|last1=UK|first1=National Archives|title=FCO 51/41 Dhofar Liberation Front|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C6081348|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate=23 August 2017}} The DLF was established by communist (Marxist–Leninist){{cite book|author1=Peter Janke|author2=Richard Sim|title=Guerrilla and terrorist organisations: a world directory and bibliography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=spoUAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=October 1983|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-02-916150-0|page=265}} youth in [[Salalah]] in 1965. Their main aim was to secure funding for the development of the area{{cite book|author=Kendall D. Gott|title=U. S. Army and the Interagency Process: Historical Perspectives: The Proceedings of the Combat Studies Institute 2008 Military History Symposium|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ar2IHsQVRi4C&pg=PA203|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=October 2010|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-1-4379-2380-3|page=203}} and also to end the rule of the Sultan of Muscat and Oman.{{cite book|author=John Townsend|title=Oman: the måking of a modern state|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f9kOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA98|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=1977|publisher=C. Helm|isbn=978-0-85664-446-7|page=98}} The two leadership characters that would be at the core of the Front's short history were [[Musallam bin Nufl]] and [[Yusuf bin Alawi bin Abdullah]].{{cite book|last1=Valeri|first1=Marc|title=Oman: Politics and Society in the Qaboos State|date=2009|publisher=Hurst|isbn=9781850659334|page=60|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MKzlyho2KQkC&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=Musallim+%22bin+Nufl%22+dhofar+oman&source=bl&ots=HRmxLnSK9Y&sig=lJloanjtAK7caMqK4v2PGH88Rl4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKgeKzhe3VAhUJDcAKHUWhAKEQ6AEIRjAI#v=onepage&q=Musallim%20%22bin%20Nufl%22%20dhofar%20oman&f=false|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Peterson|first1=J. E.|title=Oman's Insurgencies: The Sultanate's Struggle for Supremacy|date=2013|publisher=Saqi|isbn=9780863567025|page=200|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wkUhBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT150&lpg=PT150&dq=%22Yusuf+bin+Alawi%22+dissident+Oman&source=bl&ots=4qDCk5Y3L8&sig=MgirdPegEZyT8AwJu08csJeSDQE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjVpY3Knu3VAhXBK8AKHVYHC1MQ6AEIQTAH#v=onepage&q=%22Yusuf%20bin%20Alawi%22%20dissident%20Oman&f=false|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}} They, being supported by South Yemen, [[Dhofar Rebellion|fought a 10-year insurgency]] against the [[Sultan of Oman's Armed Forces|Sultan of Muscat and Oman's Armed Forces]]. The sultanate army supported by [[Iran]] and [[UK]] have managed to remove the DLF and push its forces towards the border of Yemen and the mountains in 1976. The front still exists as a political group operating from [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]{{Citation Needed|date=October 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1965 establishments in Oman]] [[Category:1968 disestablishments in Oman]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Oman]] [[Category:Arab nationalist militant groups]] [[Category:Arab Nationalist Movement]] [[Category:Arab socialist organizations]] [[Category:Communism in Oman]] [[Category:Communism in Yemen]] [[Category:National liberation movements]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1968]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1965]] {{Poli-org-stub}}

{{update|date=August 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} [[File:Earthquake Early Warning (Japan).svg|thumb|upright=1.5|When two or more [[seismometer]]s{{cite web|title=Earthquakes and Tsunamis - Disaster prevention and mitigation efforts|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/kishou/books/jishintsunami/jishintsunami.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2016}} detect [[P-wave]]s (top), the [[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]] analyzes the readings and distributes warning information broadcast stations and [[mobile phone]] companies before the arrival of [[S-wave]]s (bottom).|alt=Two illustrations of the system]] In [[Japan]], an {{Nihongo|'''Earthquake Early Warning''' ('''EEW''')|緊急地震速報|Kinkyū Jishin Sokuhō}} is a warning issued when an earthquake is detected.{{cite news|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/en/Activities/eew1.html|title=What is the Earthquake Early Warning (or "緊急地震速報 (Kinkyu Jishin Sokuho)" in Japanese)?|date=2007-08-30|accessdate=2008-06-29|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency}} The warnings are primarily issued by the [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] (JMA), with guidance on how to react to them.{{cite news|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/en/Activities/EEW_Starting_1_October_2007_Dos_and_Donts.pdf|title=Earthquake Early Warning Starting 1 October 2007|date=2007-08-30|accessdate=2008-06-29|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency}}{{cite web|url= http://www.nhk.or.jp/bousai/k/kokoroe.html|title=How to respond to earthquake early warnings|publisher=[[NHK]] (Japan Broadcasting Corporation)|accessdate=2009-05-09|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905182615/http://www.nhk.or.jp/bousai/k/kokoroe.html|archivedate=5 September 2009|df=dmy-all}} {{External media|audio1=[http://www.nhk.or.jp/sonae/bousai/ Earthquake Early Warning alarm] from [[NHK]][http://www.eewrk.org/eewrk_hochi-on/eewrk_hochi-on.html giving guidelines] by [[:ja:伊福部達]]Sankei-MSN News (2011-05-01 21:55) "The Earthquake Early Warning - the chime contained the tone of pains, even examined the 'Godzilla'" {{cite web|language=ja|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110501/dst11050121570027-n1.htm|title=緊急地震速報…チャイムに苦心の音色　「ゴジラ」の検討も|date=2011-05-01|publisher=[[MSN]]|accessdate=2011-06-26|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713125134/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110501/dst11050121570027-n1.htm|archivedate=13 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} |audio2=[http://www.real-time.jp/signwave/reicsign.html Earthquake Early Warning] from the Real-time Earthquake Information Center[http://www.real-time.jp/signwave/reicsign.html guidelines for use]}} ==Introduction== The JMA has two EEW systems: one for the general public and another for the National Meteorological and Hydrological Services. http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/en/NMHS/indexe_nmhs.html{{cite news|url=http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/eew_naiyou.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報について｜緊急地震速報の内容|date=|accessdate=2008-06-29|publisher=[[Japan Meteorological Agency]]|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312083958/http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/eew_naiyou.html|archivedate=12 March 2008|df=dmy-all}} When a [[P-wave]] is detected from two (or more) of the 4,235 [[seismometer]]s installed throughout Japan, the JMA analyzes and predicts the approximate location of the earthquake's [[epicenter]]. This allows the JMA to notify people in affected [[prefectures of Japan|prefectures]] by TV and radio if a strong earthquake is expected. An Earthquake Early Warning is issued to warn the general public when an earthquake of 5 or higher on the [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|Japan seismic scale]] is expected.{{cite web|url=http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/eew_naiyou.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報のしくみと予報・警報|publisher=[[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]]|location=Tokyo|language=ja|trans-title=About EEW alert and forecast|accessdate=2011-04-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312083958/http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/eew_naiyou.html|archivedate=12 March 2008|df=dmy-all}} An EEW forecast (緊急地震速報(予報)) is issued to the National Meteorological and Hydrological Services when an earthquake of 3 or higher on the Japan seismic scale (or 3.5 or higher on the [[Richter magnitude scale]]) is expected, or when the [[amplitude]] of P- or [[S-wave]]s measures more than 100 [[Gal (unit)|gals]]. The system was developed to minimize earthquake damage and enable people to take shelter or evacuate dangerous areas before the arrival of its strong surface waves. It is used by railways to slow trains and by factories to halt assembly lines before the earthquake hits. The effectiveness of the warning depends on the position of the receiver. After receiving a warning, a person has from a few seconds to a minute or more to take action. Areas near an epicenter may experience strong tremors before a warning is issued.{{cite news|url=http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/Whats_EEW.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報とは|date=|accessdate=2008-06-29|publisher=[[Japan Meteorological Agency]]|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080701195137/http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/eq/EEW/kaisetsu/Whats_EEW.html|archivedate=1 July 2008|df=dmy-all}} After the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]], the EEW system and Japan's [[tsunami warning system]] were considered effective. Although the tsunami killed over 10,000 people, it is believed that the casualties would have been much higher without the EEW system.{{cite news|title=Early warning system saved Japan worst of tsunami wrath|author=Amitabh Sinha|newspaper=[[Indian Express]]|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/early-warning-system-saved-japan-worst-of-tsunami-wrath/761448/|date=2011-03-12|accessdate=2018-06-11}} In April 2011, the [[Chile]]an Subsecretary of Telecommunications said that their country hoped to establish a similar early-warning system.{{cite web|url=http://nextvnews.com/the-japanese-earthquake-pushed-isdb-t-alert-system-in-chile/|title=The Japanese earthquake pushed ISDB-T alert system in Chile|date=2011-04-01|publisher=NexTV Latam, TV Telco Latam|accessdate=2018-06-11}} =={{anchor|Hit rate}}Hit rate== The JMA announced the Earthquake Early Warning hit (accuracy) rate for the 2011 [[fiscal year#Japan|fiscal year]] on 31 May 2012. The hit rate is the percentage of warnings issued immediately on the detection of [[P-wave]]s with a {{nihongo|[[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale]]|震度|shindo}} number (0 to 7) within one shindo number of the measured earthquake.{{cite web|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/kishou/hyouka/hyouka-report/24report/24shiryo.pdf|script-title=ja:平成24年報道発表資料|date=2012-05-31|publisher=[[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]]|location=Tokyo|page=25/147 sheet, page 2–15|language=ja|trans-title=Fiscal year 2012 (Heisei 24) press release, ''Material No.2 FY 2011 (Heisei 23) task review report''|format=PDF|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{clarify|date=November 2018|reason=This needs further explanation.}} For the fiscal years 2007–2009, the hit rate was 75 percent or higher (75 percent in 2007, 82 percent in 2008 and 76 percent in 2009). The 2010 hit rate fell to 28 percent, due to the number of [[aftershock]]s following the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake (which occurred near the end of the 2010 fiscal year); before the earthquake, the hit rate was 72 percent. Measurement techniques have since been refined to ignore minor earthquakes, and the hit rate for FY2011 increased to 56 percent. The JMA intended to increase the hit rate to over 85 percent by FY2015. ==={{anchor|False alarms}}Inaccuracies=== Although EEW accuracy has been increasing, the following erroneous alarms have been issued: *March 11, 2011 - The earthquake warning for the Tohoku region underestimated the quake's intensity.{{cite web|url=https://www.data.jma.go.jp/svd/eew/data/nc/oshirase/20110311.pdf|script-title=ja:東北地方を中心とした地域で発生する地震に係る緊急地震速報（予報及び警報）の発表について|trans-title=On the announcement of the emergency earthquake warning (forecast and alarm) related to the earthquake occurring in the area mainly in the Tohoku region|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja|date=2011-03-11|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{clarify|date=April 2018}} *August 8, 2013 - Although an emergency earthquake bulletin was announced at 16:56 JST from Kanto to Kyushu, no shaking was observed. Noise from the ocean-floor seismograph off southeastern [[Mie Prefecture]] was recorded at the same time as shaking from a [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale#Scale explanation|magnitude 2.3]] earthquake in northern [[Wakayama Prefecture]].{{cite web|url=https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/1308/08b/0808_wakayama_eew.htm|script-title=ja:8月8日16時56分頃の和歌山県北部を震源とする地震に関する緊急地震速報について|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja|date=2013-08-08|accessdate=2018-06-11}} *January 5, 2018 - An 11:02 JST earthquake warning for the [[Kantō region]] and [[Fukushima Prefecture]] was an overestimation, caused by assessing concurrent earthquakes in [[Toyama Prefecture]] (magnitude 3.9) and [[Ibaraki Prefecture]] (magnitude 4.4) as a single quake.{{cite web|url=https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/1801/05a/20180105eew.pdf|script-title=ja:平成30年1月5日11時02分頃に発表した緊急地震速報（警報）について|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja|date=2018-01-05|accessdate=2018-06-11}} ==={{anchor|Technical improvement}}Improvements=== Technical improvements are being made to increase the hit rate, including the Integrated Particle Filter (IPF) and Propagation of Local Undamped Motion (PLUM) methods. The IPF method, introduced on December 14, 2016, obtains seismic source elements with a [[particle filter]].{{cite web|url=https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/1612/13a/EEW_kaizen_201612.pdf|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報の技術的な改善（IPF法）等について|trans-title=Technical Improvement of Earthquake Early Warning (IPF Method) etc.|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja |date= 2016-12-13 |accessdate= 2018-06-11}}{{cite web |url= https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/1612/13a/EEW_kaizen_201612_IPF.pdf |script-title= ja:同時に複数の地震が発生した場合の緊急地震速報の技術的な改善についてーIPF法の運用開始ー |publisher= Japan Meteorological Agency |language=ja |date= 2016-12-13 |accessdate= 2018-06-11 }} The PLUM method, introduced on March 22, 2018, predicting the seismic intensity directly from observed intensity without estimating the [[hypocenter]] and scale. Accurate seismic-intensity forecasts can be made for large earthquakes or those whose hypocenter is unknown.{{cite web|url=https://www.data.jma.go.jp/svd/eew/data/nc/shiryo/setsumeikai170712/170712_7.pdf|script-title=ja:PLUM法の概要|trans-title=Outline of PLUM method|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja|date=2017-07-12|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{cite web|url=https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/1803/08c/EEW_kaizen_201803.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報の技術的改善について ～巨大地震が発生した場合の震度の予想精度が向上します～|trans-title=Technical Improvement of Earthquake Early Warning - Improvement of prediction accuracy of seismic intensity in the event of a huge earthquake|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|language=ja|date=2018-03-08|accessdate=2018-06-11}} =={{anchor|Format of EEW broadcasts}}Broadcast format== ===Television=== On [[NHK]] television channels and other Japanese TV broadcasters ([[ISDB]], including [[1seg]]),[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg-yn_sGT90 8 Japanese Channels broadcasting the EEW simultaneously.] an alert is a message window on the screen with the earthquake epicenter and areas affected by strong tremors. Two sets of chimes sound, followed by a voice announcement in Japanese: {{Nihongo|"This is an Earthquake Early Warning. Please prepare for powerful tremors."|「緊急地震速報です。強い揺れに警戒して下さい。」|Kinkyū Jishin Sokuhō desu. Tsuyoi yure ni keikai shite kudasai.}} In addition to NHK, the announcement is used by [[Fuji TV]], [[TV Asahi]] and [[Tokyo MX]]. [[Nippon TV]] and [[TBS Television|TBS]] shorten it to ''"Kinkyū Jishin Sokuhō desu"'' ("This is an Earthquake Early Warning"). [[TV Tokyo]] sounds a set of chimes, without a voice announcement. The alerts also inform viewers of possible [[landslide]]s or a [[tsunami]] caused by the quake in the affected area. If [[tsunami warning]]s are issued, the system utilizes [[1seg]] to automatically turn on (and tune to NHK) all radios and televisions with [[1seg]] technology in at-risk areas. In addition to Japanese, the warnings are broadcast in English, Mandarin, Korean and Portuguese.[https://youtube.com/watch?v=qMNu8Y1jIlU&t=3m39s Tsunami Warning in multiple languages.] ==={{anchor|Mobile phone networks}}Mobile-phone networks=== Japan's three major mobile phone carriers—[[NTT docomo]], [[au (mobile phone company)|au]] ([[KDDI]] and Okinawa Cellular) and [[SoftBank Mobile]]—have developed [[Cell Broadcast]] systems to send multiple users an SMS of the EEW.{{cite news|url=https://www.nttdocomo.co.jp/info/news_release/page/070530_02.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報に対応した一斉同報配信基盤を開発|publisher=NTT DoCoMo|date=2007-05-30|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kddi.com/corporate/news_release/2007/0530c/index.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報に対応した一斉同報配信基盤を開発|publisher=KDDI|date=2007-05-30|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{cite news|url=https://www.softbank.jp/corp/group/sbm/news/press/2007/20070530_02/|script-title=ja:「緊急地震速報」について|publisher=SoftBank Mobile|date=2007-05-30|accessdate=2018-06-11}} It is mandatory for 3G cell phones sold after 2007 to receive this service, although foreign manufacturers such as Nokia, Apple, HTC, LG and Samsung are exempt. In August 2011, Apple announced that its iOS 5 iPhone platform would support EEW notification.{{cite web|url=http://9to5mac.com/2011/08/21/ios-5-includes-early-earthquake-warning-notifications-for-japanese-iphone-users/|title=iOS 5 includes early earthquake warning notifications for Japanese iPhone users|date=2011-08-21|accessdate=2018-06-11}} ====NTT docomo==== EEW is enabled by default on all models of the {{nihongo|[[FOMA]] 905i series|[[:ja:FOMA#905iシリーズ|FOMA 905iシリーズ]]}} released after November 26, 2007, and on some FOMA high-speed models in the {{nihongo|FOMA 705i series|[[:ja:FOMA#705iシリーズ|FOMA 705iシリーズ]]}} released after February 2008.[http://pc.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/NEWS/20071002/283581/][[CEATEC]] ドコモの905i、緊急地震速報を無償で受信可能に（Nikkei ITPro 2 October 2007）{{cite web|url=https://www.nttdocomo.co.jp/service/areamail/index.html|script-title=ja:緊急速報「エリアメール」|trans-title=Emergency bulletin "area mail"|publisher=NTT DoCoMo|language=ja|date=2007-05-30|accessdate=2018-06-11}} ====au==== The system was enabled on all models in early 2008, including [[:ja:W61CA|W61CA]], [[:ja:W61H|W61H]], [[:ja:W61K|W61K]], [[:ja:W61SA|W61SA]], [[:ja:W61SH|W61SH]], [[:ja:W62SA|W62SA]] and a few [[smartphone]] models, such as [[:ja:IS02|IS02]] (TSI01). KDDI and Okinawa Cellular began free EEW broadcasts via au's [[Short Message Service|SMS]], {{nihongo|[[C-mail]]|[[:ja:Cメール]]}}, on March 25, 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.kddi.com/corporate/news_release/2008/0324/index.html|script-title=ja:緊急地震速報の提供開始について|publisher=[[KDDI Corporation]]|language=ja|date=2008-03-24|accessdate=2018-06-11}} ====SoftBank Mobile==== On May 30, 2007, [[SoftBank]] announced development of an EEW broadcast system similar to NTT docomo's and au's.{{cite web|url=http://broadband.mb.softbank.jp/corporate/release/pdf/20070530_2j.pdf|script-title=ja:「緊急地震速報」について|trans-title=About "Earthquake Early Warning"|publisher=[[SoftBank]]|date=2007-05-30}}{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722124624/http://broadband.mb.softbank.jp/corporate/release/pdf/20070530_2j.pdf|date=22 July 2011}} Deployment of the system was originally planned for FY2008, but was postponed for two years. On August 25, 2010, EEW service began on [[Shikoku]], in the [[Kansai region|Kansai]], [[Tōkai region|Tōkai]], [[Tōhoku region|Tōhoku]] (seven prefectures) and [[Chūgoku region]]s, and portions of the [[Kantō region]]. The EEW broadcast network has covered the whole country since December 7, 2010. The [[:ja:SoftBank 831N|SoftBank 831N]] was the only model supporting EEW in March 2011, although more models had been expected to support the system after summer 2010. ====Other==== RC Solution Company developed Yurekuru Call for iPhone, a free [[iPhone]] application to receive EEW which is distributed on the Apple [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]]; the application is also available for Android. Notification of an EEW might be delayed or blocked if communication lines are congested.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcsc.co.jp/yurekuru-c21q4|script-title=ja:ゆれくるコール"for iPhone サポートサイト|publisher=RC Solution Co.|date=2011-03-14|accessdate=2018-06-11}}{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ascii.jp/elem/000/000/028/28965/|script-title=ja:あと何秒で地震が来るか分かるiPhoneアプリに惚れた！|publisher=Weekly ASCII PLUS|date=2010-11-30|accessdate=2018-06-11}} The Japanese version of [[iOS 5]] for iPhone has built-in EEW functionality. ==={{anchor|Radio receivers}}Radio=== [[File:Earthquake Early Warning FM Radio EAQ-001.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Two views of a white plastic radio|[[Iris Ohyama]] EQA-001 FM EEW radio, front ''(upper)'' and rear views]] A specific, common [[Chime (bell instrument)|chime]] tone from [[Frequency modulation|FM]] stations is automatically detected and turns on the radio (if in [[sleep mode]]), sounding a loud chime and broadcasting an EEW message before the quake begins by detecting [[Seismic wave|S-waves]]. When the S-wave has been analyzed, detailed information on the earthquake (such as [[seismic scale]] and areas under threat) is announced. The following radios receive EEWs from radio stations and are free of information or connection fees: *[[Iris Ohyama]] EQA-001{{cite news|url=https://www.irisohyama.co.jp/news/2009/0820.html|script-title=ja:揺れる前に音声で地震を警告する家庭用防災用品『緊急地震速報機』を発売|publisher=Iris Ohyama|language=ja|date=2009-08-20|accessdate=2018-06-11}} *Iris Ohyama EQA-101{{cite news|url=http://www.irisohyama.co.jp/news/2010/0310.html|script-title=ja:人が多く集まる場所の地震対策に！揺れる前に大音量で地震を警告『緊急地震速報機EQA-101』を発売|publisher=Iris Ohyama|language=ja|date=2010-03-10|accessdate=2018-06-11}} *[[Uniden]] EWR200http://www.uniden.jp/products/ewr/ewr200.html Uniden supports EEW and the {{nihongo|[[Emergency Warning System]]|[[:ja:緊急警報放送]]|Kinkyū Keihō Hōsō}} *{{nihongo|P2PQuake|[[:ja:P2P地震情報|P2P地震情報]]|P2P Jishin Jōhō}} recognizes [[NHK Radio 1]] announcers. EEW broadcasts can be received in areas without [[broadband Internet access]]. Signal quality, speed and service area may vary from station to station. ===={{anchor|Radio Stations with the EEW System}}Stations==== *[[NHK Radio 1]] and [[NHK Radio 2|Radio 2]], nationwide *[[bay FM (Japan)|JOGV-FM (bayfm78)]], [[Chiba Prefecture|Chiba]][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U7RHG-28sZM&feature=related Bay FM's Earthquake Early Warning] *[[Tokyo FM|JOAU-FM (Tokyo FM)]], [[Tokyo]][http://www.tfm.co.jp/eew/ Tokyo FM's Earthquake Early Warning] *[[J-Wave|JOAV-FM (J-Wave)]], [[Tokyo]][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=661EJrCAcGI&feature=related J-Wave's Earthquake Early
